reviews.review_msg: I took this course to begin urban planning, not read and write social justice papers.

A lot of homework starting in the first week. A lot of readings that are definitely not at a first-year level. Canvas says AI was used to generate assignments, while we are prohibited from using AI. TAs mark very harshly. The course is mostly about the history of planning and the people involved in planning instead of planning itself.

Laura seems like a nice person but her course content and workload was too heavy. For week 2 she assigned 3 readings along with multiple assignments. Not all assignments will counts for marks but you are unaware of which ones will count until the end of the term when she will randomly select a few assignments and grade them.

Wayyyy too much work for this course. A never ending stream of papers, readings, and participation "exercises." Lecture recordings were nothing special. Grading was really tough too, and was more focused on writing than content. She did seem to be pretty responsive to students though. Glad it's over.

Did not enjoy her class. Even though I feel that I understood the content at the end of the day, the means of delivery were not there. Poor and vague lectures, poor feedback, and a course that assesses you based on your ability to conform to her designated writing standards rather than illustrate your knowledge of the topic. Disappointing.

She's a very nice professor but does assign too much work. Not a writing class but you'll need to write quality essays. I wouldn't recommend taking her course unless you absolutely need it. She assigns 2-3 readings along with at least 2 assignments weekly - the kicker is only 5 will matter so lots of wasted effort since she grades them at random.
I took both PLAN 100 and 300 with her. She is a great professor that wants you to put in work and that's up to you if you do it or not.
super nice prof!

An introduction course is supposed to be engaging and designed to attract people to the field. Laura Tate's class does not do that. This course requires way too much reading, unclear directions, and very harsh grading. You are not rewarded for understanding the course material or being curious. Do not take this course! its not worth it!

LMAO everyone complaining about "so many readings". average 2-3 readings that she provides PER PAPER, which is over the course of 2-3 weeks. dont do the work, dont expect a good grade. dont trust the bad reviews they seem like 1st years who dont understand how uni works

As a 5th year student taking PLAN100 for the first time it's just a regular introductory class with a fair amount of assignments. Everyone's complaining about the amount of work/discussions every week but they fail to realize we have zero exams. Just do the lectures and readings and you'll do fine since she gives clear grading instructions.

Just want to put it out there: she deducted marks from people in the course for using similar supporting arguments in their essays. It's almost like if you give people the same lecture recordings, the same reading material, and the same instructions, they will produce and utilize similar results and supporting arguments lmao
terrible terrible terrible do not take her, you will spend more time on plan 100 than your three other courses combined. TA's also mark like they're marking graduate papers, level 100 course btw.

For a 100 level course, she and her TAs are extremely harsh markers. Many of her essay assignments are lacking in specificity, leading to a lot of questions or things that you may just have to leave up to your own interpretation.

Also there's a buuunch of readings and videos every week.

This class hardly felt like an introduction to urban planning. The lectures were incredibly lackluster and surface level, and I can't really say I learned anything I didn't already know. The assignments are somewhat vague so you better pray you get a T.A. that actually responds to you. Ultimately a very unorganized and pointless class.

She assigns way too much work for a 100-level class + a lot of readings next to multiple lecture videos. Overall spent more time in this class than I needed to. She wasn't exactly tech-savvy either, would always have something wrong with the canvas pages every week. Maybe this class is better in person i wouldn't know, but it was terrible online.

400-500 word discussions weekly... harshly graded. Mind you this is a 100-level course, and marking is extremely hard, and most of her announcements and instructions are so wordy and lengthy that it is difficult to understand them. Plus there are assignments that are not chosen till the end of the semester and are marked "randomly graded" ?!

Dr. Tate teaches a class that cares way too much about forcing a writing method down your throat rather than teaching the material that actually matters. For an introductory course, I feel like I barely got a taste for what the field of planning actually teaches about. Workload is far too heavy for 100 class, and grading is tough.

Way too much writing. No midterms or finals. Be prepared to write 400 word discussions every week. Most of your grade is based on 1000+ word essays on historical papers. Harshly graded for a 100-level class. Focuses too much on writing skills instead of the actual topic of the modules. A few interesting videos within lecture material. Don't take.

If you're not into planning, then the amount of work you do may feel diluted. But she is very focused on a "learn by doing" approach. Now that I'm doing my upper-division courses in Planning, I have been heavily relying on what I learned from her courses. Please take her course seriously, and you will reap the benefits of learning experientially.

Ridiculous amount of reading (which I didn't do). Instructions for her overly writing-focused assignments were wordy, uninformative, and confusing. Never responded to emails, not even one. Confusing grading. Slides contain no actual info. Didn't even learn about planning because of the focus on writing perfection. Don't take!

Very kind professor contrasted by huge workload. Assignment every tutorial, before and after lectures. Mandatory prep work is rarely graded in time to build off for larger assignments. So far, small assignments are not graded until randomly selected for grading at the end of semester making it very hard to learn from mistakes. Not worth the effort.

Do not take her. I wish I followed my gut feeling and dropped this course before the deadline. She assigns so much work for a FIRST YEAR CLASS. And way too many group projects I couldn't care less about. She assigns pre-class, in-class, and after-class assignments almost weekly that require you to do at least 2 readings to complete it. not worth it

Laura is very passionate about the material, however, her class requires many homework assignments before, during, and after lectures and before/in tutorials consist of major assignments. Vague criterea means this is a considerably difficult course for first years.

Grading was unclear. All assignments (of which there were a lot) were in one category worth 85%. No idea how much a paper vs weekly homework was worth. The ChatGPT critique assignment asked you to write a prompt with a 1000 word count, but the program refused to accept this. I lost marks and was told I should have asked it for a word count.

constantly positive; however, she assigns an excessive amount of assignments that are not clear. along with loads of assignments you will have weakly tutorial assignments and loads of group work. she assigns an assignment before class, during class, after class, a tutorial assignment in tutorial and one after, also 4 big essays. LOL

she literally eliminated an assignment right after I finished it. confusing af in class. lectures are 3 hrs long with group work. would've been better if it was 2 hours lecture & 1 hr tutorial cuz we have to scramble around to find out groups every class. never again..........
She's really simple, fun, and good at what she does. Most of the grading is done by the TA's so ig just pray you get a good TA. Very easy course otherwise and 10% of your grade is just being there

I liked this professor a lot, but when it comes to in-class, you'll have to engage discussion with students in the lecture and at the tutorials. Also, lots of assignments that are still vague though. Even so, don't enroll this course if you're into community planning
